{{Year box}} '''1833 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * Merger of the Olympic and Camden town ball clubs from [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] and [[Camden, New Jersey]], constituting the Olympic Ball Club of Philadelphia, often called the "Philadelphia Olympics". The constitution would be revised in 1837 and published in 1838.<ref>[http://retrosheet.org/Protoball/chron.htm Protoball 1831.1 – Ball Club Forms in Philadelphia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809204534/http://retrosheet.org/Protoball/chron.htm |date=2009-08-09 }}. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 30 May — [[James Burke (boxer)|James Burke]] defeats [[Simon Byrne]] in 99 rounds. There are serious concerns about Byrne's health in the aftermath of the fight.<ref name="JB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/burke-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – James Burke]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref> * 2 June — Byrne dies of injuries from the fight and Burke is arrested.<ref name="JB"/> * 11 July — at Burke's trial, he is exonerated from blame for Byrne's death.<ref name="JB"/> * Controversy about the English title continues as the now retired [[Jem Ward]] refuses to recognise Burke. The death of Byrne effectively ruins Burke's career and he is stigmatised.<ref name="JB"/>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[John Nyren]] publishes ''The Cricketers Of My Time'' which has been serialised in ''The Town'' during the previous year * First use by [[Sheffield Cricket Club]] of Yorkshire as a team name instead of Sheffield '''England''' * Most runs – [[Tom Marsden]] 181 @ 16.45 (HS 53) * Most wickets – [[William Lillywhite]] 37 (BB 6–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Tarantella (horse)|Tarantella]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Clearwell * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Dangerous (horse)|Dangerous]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Vespa (horse)|Vespa]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Rockingham (horse)|Rockingham]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year

{{Year box}} '''1855 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * The established [[New York Knickerbockers|Knickerbockers]], Gothams, and Eagles from New York (Manhattan) play three matches [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] in June. With the Empires, a local newcomer, they play five matches in September and October, a [[Round-robin tournament|round-robin]] less one match. * A few clubs from outside New York (Manhattan) play their first matches in the fall. One from Brooklyn is the [[Brooklyn Atlantics|Atlantic Base Ball Club]] or simply "Atlantic", soon to be the first recurring winner or "dynasty".
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[John Morrissey]] retains the Championship of America but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1855.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 20 February and 12 March — English Champion [[Harry Broome]] twice fails to honour scheduled bouts against [[Tom Paddock]] but continues to be recognised as the champion.<ref name="HB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/broome-h.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Harry Broome]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 25 February — [[William Poole]] is shot dead in New York by supporters of [[John Morrissey]].<ref name="JM"/> * 26 June — Paddock keeps up the pressure on Broome by winning a return bout with [[Aaron Jones (boxer)|Aaron Jones]] in 61 rounds at Mildenhall.<ref name="TP">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/paddock.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Paddock]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 30 April — [[Bramall Lane]] stadium in Sheffield opens as a cricket ground and stages a match between two local teams. It is first used by [[Sheffield Cricket Club]] (''aka'' Yorkshire) in August for a first-class match against [[Sussex County Cricket Club|Sussex]]. '''England''' * Most runs – [[John Wisden]] 422 @ 28.13 (HS 148) * Most wickets – [[Jemmy Dean]] 98 @ 11.47 (BB 8–38)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1855 Grand National|Grand National]] – Wanderer * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Habena * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Lord of the Isles * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Wild Dayrell]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Marchioness * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Saucebox
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * It is about this time that pucks are introduced to the game in Canada in place of balls
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year. '''Other''' * 21 July — Harvard wins the second [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]] by a 1:38 margin on the [[Connecticut River]] in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]]. With the first in 1852 and the third in 1859, at three different sites, the one-race "regatta" is an occasional rather than a traditional or an established event.<ref name=150yrs>[http://www.gocrimson.com/sports/mcrew-hw/tradition/harvard-yale-regatta "Harvard–Yale Regatta – 150 Years of Tradition"]. Harvard Men's Heavyweight Crew. Retrieved 2013-05-10.</ref><!-- source does not cover every point -->

{{Year box}} '''1916 in sports''' describes the year’s events in world sport.
Note — ''many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War I]]''
==[[American football]]== [[File:GT Cumberland 222 scoreboard.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Final score of the [[1916 Cumberland vs. Georgia Tech football game]]]] '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Pittsburgh Panthers]] '''Events''' * 7 October — [[Georgia Institute of Technology|Georgia Tech]] [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Engineers]] defeats the [[Cumberland University|Cumberland College]] Bulldogs by a score of 222–0, the most one-sided game in college football history.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news| work=[[The New York Times]]| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/07/sports/ncaafootball/07tech.html| accessdate=2008-02-09| date=2006-10-07| title=In 1916, a Blowout for the Ages| last=Litsky| first=Frank}}</ref>
==[[Association football]]== '''Europe''' * There is no major football in Europe due to [[World War I]] '''South America''' * 9 July — [[CONMEBOL]], the governing body of South American football, is founded
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * 2 September: [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] wins the 20th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: Fitzroy 12.13 (85) d [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] 8.8 (56) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG). Fitzroy wins the title despite having finished last in the regular season. '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''': * not contested due to World War I '''[[West Australian Football League]]''': * 9 September: [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 7.12 (54) defeat [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 5.5 (35) for their first WAFL premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 3–2 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 7–12 October — [[1916 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]] defeats [[1916 Brooklyn Robins season|the Brooklyn Robins]] by 4 games to 1 to win the [[1916 World Series]]. '''Events''' * [[1916 Philadelphia Athletics season|The Philadelphia Athletics]] finish the season with a record of 36–117 or a .235 winning percentage, the worst Major League Baseball record since 1900. * [[Winnipeg Maroons]] wins the [[Northern League (baseball, 1902-71)|Northern League]] Championship * The [[Federal League]] goes out of business in a settlement with organised baseball that leaves out one club; the [[Baltimore Terrapins]] pursue a legal remedy
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * Having already lost to him earlier in the year, [[Battling Levinsky]] defeats [[Jack Dillon]] in 12 rounds at [[Boston]] to claim the [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship. * The series of fights between [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] and [[Jack Britton]] continues with Britton taking the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship into 1917. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jess Willard]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dillon]] → [[Battling Levinsky]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Al McCoy (boxer)|Al McCoy]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] → [[Jack Britton]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Freddie Welsh]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Kid Williams]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * There is no [[first-class cricket]] in England, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa or the West Indies due to [[World War I]] '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France general classification winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]] '''[[List of Giro d'Italia general classification winners|Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural [[PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] is held as a [[matchplay]] tournament '''Major tournaments''' * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * June 29–30 — [[1916 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Chick Evans]] * October 10–14 — [[1916 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Jim Barnes]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Chick Evans]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1916 Grand National|Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War I]]'' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Canyon (horse)|Canyon]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Clarissimus (horse)|Clarissimus]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Fifinella (horse)|Fifinella]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Fifinella * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Hurry On]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Sasanof '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Mandarin '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – All Sorts * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Furore '''USA''' * May 13 — [[1916 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – George Smith * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Damrosch * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Friar Rock
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Montreal Canadiens]] wins the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) championship * [[Portland Rosebuds (hockey)|Portland Rosebuds]] wins the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] (PCHA) championship, the first United States team to do so * 20–30 March — Montreal Canadiens defeats Portland Rosebuds in the [[1916 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2 '''Events''' * [[Winnipeg 61st Battalion]] wins the [[1916 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]]
==[[Motor racing]]== {{main|1916 in motorsport|List of 1916 motorsport champions}}
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1916 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1916 Summer Olympics]], due to take place in [[Berlin]], are cancelled due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] – not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * All first-class competitions are cancelled due to [[World War I]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] 5–3 [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (grand final) '''New Zealand''' *[[1916 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men’s Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men’s Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women’s Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Richard Norris Williams]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis player)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 4–6 6–4 0–6 6–2 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women’s Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Louise Hammond Raymond]] (USA) 6–0 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * 1916 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''

{{Year box}} '''1924 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== * [[History of National Football League Championship|NFL Championship]] – [[Cleveland Bulldogs]] *[[Anthracite League|Anthracite League champions]] – [[Pottsville Maroons]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Huddersfield Town]] 57 points, [[Cardiff City]] 57, [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] 53, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 50, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 50, [[Aston Villa]] 49 * [[1924 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Newcastle United]] 2–0 [[Aston Villa]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[1. FC Nürnberg]] 2–0 [[Hamburger SV]] at Berlin '''Greece''' * [[AEK Athens]] officially founded on April 13.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} '''Monaco''' * [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] officially founded on August 23.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 1500 metres''' * [[Paavo Nurmi]] (Finland) breaks the world record by running a time of 3:52.6 at [[Helsinki]].
'''England''' * [[1924 Women's Olympiad]], [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], London
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 28th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: under the finals system used, no Grand Final is played. '''Brownlow Medal''' * The inaugural [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Edward Greeves]] of [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]].
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[Västerås SK Bandy|Västerås SK]] 4–1 [[IF Linnéa]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 4–10 October — [[Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]] (AL) defeats [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1924 World Series]] by 4 games to 3 '''Negro League Baseball''' * [[Kansas City Monarchs]] ([[Negro National League (1920–1931)|NNL]]) defeats [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] ([[Eastern Colored League|ECL]]) 5 games to 4 with 1 tie in the first official [[1924 Colored World Series|Negro League World Series]]. * Pitcher [[Nip Winters]] wins a record 27 games for [[Hilldale Club|Hilldale]] in the ECL regular season.
==[[Biathlon]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Military patrol]], the forerunner of [[biathlon]] which combines [[cross-country skiing]] and [[shooting sports|rifle shooting]], is staged as a demonstration event at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]] in [[Chamonix]]. The winning team is Switzerland.
==[[Bobsleigh]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Bobsleigh debuts oaiusfhkuhoidsfuhoiuhin [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. The sole event is the 4-man bob which is won by Switzerland I (gold) ahead of Great Britain II (silver) and Belgium I (bronze).
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 10 August — the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship title becomes vacant as [[Johnny Dundee]] relinquishes it to fight as a lightweight '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Dempsey]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike McTigue]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Harry Greb]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Dundee]] → vacant * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Joe Lynch (boxer)|Joe Lynch]] → [[Abe Goldstein]] → Eddie "Cannonball" Martin * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Francisco Guilledo|Pancho Villa]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[12th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – Queen's University 11–2 [[Toronto Balmy Beach Beachers|Toronto Balmy Beach]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[England national cricket team|England]] defeats [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] 3–0 with two matches drawn. There is a sensational start to the series when the South Africans are bowled out for only 30, in just 12.3 overs, in their first innings of the First Test at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]], England having made over 400. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Berkshire County Cricket Club|Berkshire]] * Most runs – [[Frank Woolley]] 2344 @ 49.87 (HS 202) * Most wickets – [[Maurice Tate]] 205 @ 13.74 (BB 8–18) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Bob Catterall]], [[Jack MacBryan]], [[Herbie Taylor]], [[Dick Tyldesley]], [[Dodger Whysall]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Bill Ponsford]] 777 @ 111.00 (HS 248) * Most wickets – [[Albert Hartkopf]] and [[Norman Williams (Australian cricketer)|Norman Williams]] 26 apiece '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Curling]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Curling is played at the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]]. It is a demonstration sport at the time but is retrospectively granted official status. The gold medal is won by the Great Britain and Ireland team.
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Ottavio Bottecchia]] (Italy) wins the 18th [[1924 Tour de France|Tour de France]]
==[[Field hockey]]== '''Events''' * 7 January — the [[International Hockey Federation]] (FIH) is founded in Paris by seven member countries: Austria, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Hungary, Spain and Switzerland.
==[[Figure skating]]== '''Events''' * Figure skating is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1908 Summer Olympics|1908]] and [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. The Olympic gold medallists and the world championship winners are the same in all three events. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Men's individual – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * Women's individual – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * Pairs – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria) '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gillis Grafström]] (Sweden) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Herma Szabo]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Helene Engelmann and Alfred Berger (Austria)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1924 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Walter Hagen]] * [[1924 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Cyril Walker]] * [[1924 PGA Championship|USPGA Championship]] – [[Walter Hagen]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Ernest Holderness]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] is won by Red Splash '''England''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Red Splash]] * [[1924 Grand National|Grand National]] – Master Robert * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Plack (horse)|Plack]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Diophon]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Sansovino (horse)|Sansovino]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Straitlace]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Salmon-Trout]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Backwood '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Maternal Pride '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – Massine '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Kilbarry * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Haine ''dead heated with'' Zodiac '''USA''' * [[1924 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Black Gold * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Nellie Morse * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Mad Play
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Events''' * Ice hockey is included in the inaugural [[1924 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]], having already featured in the [[1920 Summer Olympics]]. Canada successfully defends the Olympic title. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * Gold Medal – Canada * Silver Medal – USA * Bronze Medal – Great Britain '''Stanley Cup''' * 22–25 March — [[Montreal Canadiens]] defeats [[Calgary Tigers]] by 2 games to 0 in the [[1924 Stanley Cup Finals]] '''Events''' * [[Sault Ste. Marie Greyhounds]] defeats the [[Winnipeg Selkirks]] 6–3 to win the [[Allan Cup]] * 1 December — the expansion [[Boston Bruins]] and [[Montreal Maroons]] of the NHL play their inaugural game against each other at Boston. Boston wins this game 2–1 but then lose eleven in a row.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1924 in motorsport|List of 1924 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''Events''' * Nordic skiing stages its first international competitions at the inaugural Winter Olympics in [[Chamonix]]. Four events are held (for men only): [[cross-country skiing]] over 18 km and 50 km; [[ski jumping]] on the large hill; and [[Nordic combined]] as an individual event. '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * [[Cross-country skiing]] (18 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * Cross-country skiing (50 km) – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway) * [[Ski jumping]] – gold medal: [[Jacob Tullin Thams]] (Norway) * [[Nordic combined]] – gold medal: [[Thorleif Haug]] (Norway)
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * The [[1924 Winter Olympics]], the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]], takes place in [[Chamonix]], France. It is originally called ''Semaine des Sports d'Hiver'', or "International Winter Sports Week". * Norway wins the most medals (18) and the most gold medals (5) '''1924 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1924 Summer Olympics]] takes place in Paris * United States wins the most medals (99) and the most gold medals (45)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 5 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 76th [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 21–4 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] at [[Athletic Grounds, Rochdale]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[St Helens Recreation RLFC|St Helens Recs]] 17–0 [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Hull F.C.]] 10–4 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Balmain Tigers|Balmain]] 3–0 [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (grand final)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 37th [[1924 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[England national rugby union team|England]] who complete the [[Grand Slam (rugby union)|Grand Slam]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Events''' * Speed skating debuts as an Olympic sport in [[Chamonix]] at the inaugural [[Winter Olympics]]. Five men only events are held. '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Roald Larsen]] (Norway) '''1924 Winter Olympics''' * 500m – gold medal: [[Charles Jewtraw]] (USA) * 1500m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 5000m – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland) * 10000m – gold medal: [[Julius Skutnabb]] (Finland) * All-round – gold medal: [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[James Anderson (tennis)|James Anderson]] (Australia) defeats [[Richard Schlesinger (tennis)|Richard Schlesinger]] (Australia) 6–3 6–4 3–6 5–7 6–3 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Sylvia Lance Harper]] (Australia) defeats [[Esna Boyd Robertson]] (Australia) 6–3 3–6 8–6 '''England''' * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 6–1 3–6 6–1 3–6 6–4 * [[The Championships Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Kitty McKane Godfree]] (Great Britain) defeats [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) 4–6 6–4 6–4 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[René Lacoste]] (France) 7–5 6–4 0–6 5–7 6–2 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Emilienne Didi Vlasto]] (France) defeats [[Jeanne Vaussard]] (France) 6–2 6–3 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Johnston (tennis)|Bill Johnston]] (USA) 6–1 9–7 6–2 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) 6–1 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1924 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|USA|1912}} 5–0 {{davis|AUS}} at [[Germantown Cricket Club]] (grass) [[Philadelphia]], United States

{{Year box}} '''1936 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Alpine skiing]]== '''FIS Alpine World Ski Championships''' 6th [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1936|FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]] are held at [[Innsbruck]], Austria. The events are a [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]], a [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] and a [[Alpine skiing combined|combined]] race in both the men's and women's categories. The winners are: * Men’s Downhill – [[Rudolf Rominger]] (Switzerland) * Men’s Slalom – [[Rudolph Matt]] (Austria) * Men’s Combined – [[Rudolf Rominger]] (Switzerland) * Women’s Downhill – [[Evelyn Pinching]] (Great Britain) * Women’s Slalom – [[Gerda Paumgarten]] (Austria) * Women’s Combined – [[Evelyn Pinching]] (Great Britain)
==[[American football]]== * [[1936 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] (1935 season): ** The [[SMU Mustangs]] lose 7-0 to the [[Stanford Indians]]; share national championship * [[Minnesota Golden Gophers]] – [[college football]] national championship; first season in which a national champion was declared by the [[AP Poll]]. * [[1936 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] defeated the [[1936 Boston Redskins season|Boston Redskins]] 21–6 for the [[1936 NFL Championship Game|NFL]] championship. The game was moved from Boston to New York's [[Polo Grounds]] * First [[NFL Draft]] held * Second [[American Football League (1936)|American Football League]] (AFL) founded * [[Cleveland Rams]] founded by [[Homer Marsh]] as part of AFL
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[Football League First Division|First Division]] – [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] win the [[1935–36 in English football|1935–36]] title. * [[FA Cup]] – [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] beat [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 1–0, thanks to a [[Ted Drake]] goal. '''Spain''' * [[1935–36 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Athletic Bilbao]] '''Germany''' * [[1936 German football championship|German football championship]] won by [[1. FC Nürnberg|Nürnberg]] '''Italy''' * [[1935–36 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]] '''Portugal''' * [[1935–36 Primeira Liga|Primeira Liga]] won by [[S.L. Benfica]] '''France''' * [[1935–36 French Division 1|French Division 1]] won by [[Racing Club de France football Colombes 92|RC Paris]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== * '''[[1936 VFL season|Victorian Football League]]''' ** [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] wins the 40th VFL Premiership, beating [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 11.23 (89) to 10.18 (78) in the [[1936 VFL Grand Final]]. ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Denis Ryan (footballer)|Dinny Ryan]] ([[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]]) * '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' ** 1 August: [[Glenelg Football Club|Glenelg]] 14.9 (93) defeat [[South Adelaide Football Club|South Adelaide]] 9.32 (86) despite having 23 scoring shots against South’s 41. The eighteen-shot deficit is the greatest deficit in scoring shots by a winning team in a major Australian Rules league.<ref>Cornwall, Peter and Wood, John; ''Pride of the Bay: The Story of the Glenelg Football Club''; p. 72 {{ISBN|0646378171}}</ref> ** 3 October: [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 13.19 (97) defeat [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] 14.10 (94) for their first premiership since 1929 and their eleventh overall. It is the only SANFL Grand Final where the winning team scored fewer goals than the losing team. ** [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Bill McCallum]] ([[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]]) * '''[[1936 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]''' ** 10 October: [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 11.5 (71) defeat [[Claremont Football Club|Claremont]] 9.6 (60) to win their eighth WANFL premiership. ** [[Sandover Medal]] won by [[George Moloney]] ([[Claremont Football Club|Claremont]])
==[[Baseball]]== * [[Japanese Baseball League]], as predecessor for [[Central League|Japan Central League]] and [[Pacific League|Pacific League of Japan]], a first officially game held on February 9.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} * Plans are announced for a [[Baseball Hall of Fame]] to be established in [[1939 in sports|1939]], the game's supposed centennial, in [[Cooperstown, New York]]. In the first elections to select 15 initial inductees (5 from the 19th century and 10 from the 20th), [[Ty Cobb]], [[Babe Ruth]], [[Honus Wagner]], [[Christy Mathewson]] and [[Walter Johnson]] are selected from the 20th century; the election for 19th century players is plagued by problems and results in no selections. See: [[Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1936]] * [[1936 World Series|World Series]] – [[1936 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] defeat [[1936 New York Giants (MLB) season|the New York Giants]], 4–2. * Nagoya Baseball Club, as predecessor for [[Chunichi Dragons]], officially founded in [[Japan]] on January 15.<ref>[[:ja:中日ドラゴンズ#球団の歴史#１リーグ時代]]’’’(Japanese)’’’ Retrieved January 6, 2017</ref>
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 19 June – in one of boxing’s biggest-ever upsets, [[Max Schmeling]] knocks out [[Joe Louis]] at 2:29 of round 12 at [[New York City|New York]]'s [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Braddock]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[John Henry Lewis]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Barney Ross]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Tony Canzoneri]] → [[Lou Ambers]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Sixto Escobar]] → [[Tony Marino]] → [[Sixto Escobar]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – vacant → [[Benny Lynch]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Australian national cricket team|Australia]] tours [[South African cricket team|South Africa]], winning the five-test series three tests to nil. '''[[1936 English cricket season|England]]''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Hertfordshire County Cricket Club|Hertfordshire]] * Most runs – Patsy Hendren 2,654 @ 47.39 (HS 202) * Most wickets – [[Hedley Verity]] 216 @ 13.18 (BB 9–12) * [[Indian cricket team|India]] play a three-Test series of England, losing two and drawing one * Wisden Cricketers of the Year – [[Charlie Barnett (cricketer)|Charlie Barnett]], [[Bill Copson]], [[Alf Gover]], [[Vijay Merchant]], [[Stan Worthington]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[South Australia cricket team|South Australia]] * Most runs – [[Don Bradman]] 1,173 @ 130.33 (HS 369) * Most wickets – [[Frank Ward (cricketer, born 1906)|Frank Ward]] 50 @ 20.94 (BB 6–47) '''India''' * [[Ranji Trophy]] – [[Bombay cricket team|Bombay]] beat [[Madras cricket team|Madras]] by 190 runs * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]] South Africa * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * Inter-Colonial Tournament – [[British Guiana cricket team|British Guiana]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[1936 Tour de France|Tour de France]]''' * [[Sylvère Maes]] wins the 30th Tour de France '''[[1936 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]]''' * [[Gino Bartali]] of Legnano wins the 24th Giro d'Italia
==[[Field Hockey]]== * [[Hockey at the 1936 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games (Men's Competition)]] in Berlin won by India
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1936 World Figure Skating Championships|World Figure Skating Championships]]: ** Men’s singles: [[Karl Schäfer]] ** Ladies’ singles: [[Sonja Henie]] ** Pairs: [[Maxi Herber]] and [[Ernst Baier]] * [[Figure skating at the 1936 Winter Olympics|1936 Winter Olympics]] ** Men’s singles: [[Karl Schäfer]] ** Ladies’ singles: [[Sonja Henie]] ** Pairs: [[Maxi Herber]] and [[Ernst Baier]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1936 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Horton Smith]] * [[1936 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Tony Manero (golfer)|Tony Manero]] * [[1936 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Alf Padgham]] * [[1936 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Denny Shute]] '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Hector Thomson (golfer)|Hector Thomson]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[John Fischer (golfer)|John Fischer]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Opal Hill]]
==[[Horse racing]]== * May 8 – jockey [[Ralph Neves]] was involved in a racing accident at Bay Meadows Racetrack in [[San Mateo, California]] and mistakenly pronounced dead. A while later, he woke up in the morgue and promptly returned to the racetrack but was not allowed to compete in any of the remaining races because of his "death". '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Golden Miller]] * [[1936 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Reynoldstown (horse)|Reynoldstown]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Wotan (horse)|Wotan]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Monsweep]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Corrida (horse)|Corrida]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Raeburn (horse)|Raeburn]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Pay Up (horse)|Pay Up]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Mahmoud (horse)|Mahmoud]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Boswell (horse)|Boswell]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1936 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Bold Venture (horse)|Bold Venture]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Bold Venture (horse)|Bold Venture]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Granville (horse)|Granville]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * The [[1935–36 Detroit Red Wings season|Detroit Red Wings]] win the [[1935 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup Championship]] 3 games to 1 over the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] **Combining this with the Detroit Tigers World Series win and the Detroit Lions NFL Championship, in 1935, Detroit played home to the Championship teams in the MLB, NFL, and NHL in one 12-month period. This feat has yet to be duplicated by any other city.<ref>[[Champions day]]</ref>
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1936 in motorsport|List of 1936 motorsport champions}}
==[[Olympic Games]]== * The infamous [[1936 Summer Olympics]] take place in Berlin ** Germany wins the most medals (89) and the most gold medals (33) ** [[Jesse Owens]] wins four athletics gold medals ** The first torch relay takes place from [[Olympia, Greece]] * [[1936 Winter Olympics]] takes place in [[Garmisch-Partenkirchen]], Germany ** Norway wins the most medals (15) and the most gold medals (7)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 4 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 88th [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== *[[1935–36 European Rugby League Championship]] / [[1936–37 European Rugby League Championship]] *[[1936 New Zealand rugby league season]] *[[1936 NSWRFL season]] *[[1936–37 Northern Rugby Football League season]] / [[1935–36 Northern Rugby Football League season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== * 49th [[1936 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]
==[[Snooker]]== * [[1936 World Snooker Championship|World Snooker Championship]] – [[Joe Davis]] beats [[Horace Lindrum]] 34–27
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Women]] is held in [[Stockholm]] '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Ivar Ballangrud]] (Norway) * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Women|Women's All-round Champion]] – [[Kit Klein]] (USA) '''1936 Winter Olympics (Men)''' * 500m – gold medal: [[Ivar Ballangrud]] (Norway) * 1500m – gold medal: [[Charles Mathiesen]] (Norway) * 5000m – gold medal: [[Ivar Ballangrud]] (Norway) * 10000m – gold medal: [[Ivar Ballangrud]] (Norway) '''1936 Winter Olympics (Women)''' * not contested
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Adrian Quist]] (Australia) defeats [[Jack Crawford (tennis)|Jack Crawford]] (Australia) 6–2, 6–3, 4–6, 3–6, 9–7 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Joan Hartigan Bathurst]] (Australia) defeats [[Nancye Wynne Bolton]] (Australia) 6–4, 6–4 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Fred Perry]] (Great Britain) defeats Gottfried von Cramm (Germany) 6–1, 6–1, 6–0 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Jacobs]] (USA) defeats [[Hilde Krahwinkel Sperling]] (Denmark) 6–2, 4–6, 7–5 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Gottfried von Cramm]] (Germany) defeats [[Fred Perry]] (Great Britain) 6–0, 2–6, 6–2, 2–6, 6–0 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Hilde Krahwinkel Sperling]] (Germany) defeats [[Simonne Mathieu]] (France) 6–3, 6–4 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Fred Perry]] (Great Britain) defeats [[Don Budge]] (USA) 2–6, 6–2, 8–6, 1–6, 10–8 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Alice Marble]] (USA) defeats [[Helen Jacobs]] (USA) 4–6, 6–3, 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1936 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|GBR}} at 3–2 {{davis|AUS}} at [[All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club|Centre Court, Wimbledon]] (grass) [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]
==Awards== * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Jesse Owens]], [[Track and field]] * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Helen Stephens]], [[Track and field]]

{{Year box}} '''1945 in sports''' describes the year’s events in world sport.
Note — ''many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War II]]''
==[[American football]]== * [[1945 Cleveland Rams season|Cleveland Rams]] defeated [[1945 Washington Redskins season|the Washington Redskins]] 15-14 at [[Cleveland, Ohio]] to win the [[1945 NFL Championship Game|NFL]] championship; the Rams relocate after the season to [[Los Angeles]] * [[Army Black Knights|Army Cadets]] – [[college football]] national championship
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * With the end of [[World War II]], the [[FA Cup]] is reinstated for the [[1945–46 in English football|1945–46]] season; played on a two–legged basis. However, clubs are not yet prepared for a full league programme, so the [[Football League]] does not resume; regional leagues remain for another year. '''France''' * 26 August: [[1945–46 French Division 1|French Division 1]] football is resumed for the first time since [[1938–39 French Division 1|1938–39]]. '''Germany''' * There is no major football in Germany due to World War II and [[Allied-occupied Germany|the Allied occupation]]. '''Portugal''' * [[1944–45 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[S.L. Benfica]]. '''Spain''' * [[1944-45 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. '''Italy''' * [[Serie A]] – not contested due to [[World War II]].
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[1945 VFL season|Victorian Football League]] ** Carlton wins the 49th VFL Premiership defeating [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 15.13 (103) to 10.15 (75) [[1945 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]]. * [[South Australian National Football League]]: ** 29 September: [[West Torrens Football Club|West Torrens]] win their third SANFL premiership, defeating [[Port Adelaide Football Club (SANFL)|Port Adelaide]] 15.25 (115) to 15.12 (102). * [[1945 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]: ** 29 March: After three seasons of football limited to players under 18 or 19, and a proposal to limit eligibility to players under 25, the WANFL decides to restore open-age league football.<ref>“League Football – An Open Competition: Decision for 1945 Season”; ''[[The West Australian]]'', 23 March 1945, p. 2</ref> ** 13 October: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 12.15 (87) defeat [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 7.9 (51) for their nineteenth senior WANFL premiership.
==[[Baseball]]== * [[1945 World Series|World Series]] – [[Detroit Tigers]] defeat the [[Chicago Cubs]], 4 games to 3. * [[1945 Negro World Series|Negro World Series]] – [[Cleveland Buckeyes]] swept the [[Homestead Grays]], 4 games to 0.
==[[Basketball]]== '''NBL Championship''' *[[Fort Wayne Zollner Pistons]] win three games to two over the [[Sheboygan Redskins]] '''Events''' * The twelfth [[South American Basketball Championship 1945|South American Basketball Championship]] in [[Guayaquil]] is won by [[Brazil national basketball team|Brazil]]. '''Serbia''' *[[KK Crvena zvezda]], as known well for professional basketball club of [[Serbia]], officially founded on March 3. {{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Cricket]]== '''England''' *With the end of [[European theatre of World War II|World War II in Europe]], a small number of [[first-class cricket|first-class matches]] are played for the first time since [[1939 English cricket season|1939]], but it is not practicable to resume the [[County Championship]] or the [[Minor Counties Championship]]. *Most runs – [[Len Hutton]] 782 @ 48.87 (HS 188) *Most wickets – [[Dick Pollard]] 28 @ 24.25 (BB 6–75) '''Australia''' * 23 November – With the lifting of bans on weekday sport at the end of [[World War II]], first-class cricket is played in Australia for the first time since 1 December 1941. The [[Sheffield Shield]], however, is not contested until the following season. '''India''' * 4–8 March: [[C. S. Nayudu|Cottari Subbanna Nayudu]] of [[Holkar cricket team|Holkar]] sets two first-class records in the Ranji Trophy final against [[Bombay cricket team|Bombay]], bowling 912 balls and conceding 428 runs in the match.<ref>Webber, Roy; ''The Playfair Book of Cricket Records''; pp. 163-165. Published 1951 by Playfair Books.</ref> * [[Ranji Trophy]] – Bombay beat Holkar by 374 runs * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Pentangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] '''New Zealand''' * 24 December: The [[Plunket Shield]] is resumed after having not been contested, despite a small number of interprovincial first-class matches, since 1939–40. '''South Africa''' * 15 December: With the end of [[World War II]], first-class cricket is played in South Africa for the first time since 14 March 1943, though the last regular interprovincial matches had been in 1939–40.
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]] '''[[Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War II]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[Masters Tournament]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[1945 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Byron Nelson]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Byron Nelson]] – $63,336 '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – not played due to [[World War II]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – not played due to [[World War II]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Babe Zaharias]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – not played due to [[World War II]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Red Rower]] * [[Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War II]]'' '''Hurdle races''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – [[Brains Trust (horse)|Brains Trust]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Rainbird (horse)|Rainbird]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Uttermost]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by Nikellora * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Piccadilly (horse)|Piccadilly]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Court Martial (horse)|Court Martial]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Dante (horse)|Dante]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Chamossaire (horse)|Chamossaire]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown Races]]: *# [[1945 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Hoop Jr.]] *# [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Polynesian (horse)|Polynesian]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Pavot]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== * [[1945 Stanley Cup Finals|Stanley Cup]]: [[1944–45 Toronto Maple Leafs season|Toronto Maple Leafs]] beat [[1944–45 Detroit Red Wings season|Detroit Red Wings]] four games to three.
==[[Motor racing]]== * [[Indianapolis 500]] – ''not held due to [[World War II]]'' * 9 September – The first European [[Grands Prix during World War II|Grand Prix]] since [[1939 Grand Prix season|1939]] is held in Paris, being won by [[Jean-Pierre Wimille]].
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not contested due to World War II

{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Year box}} '''1951 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport. {{TOC right}}
==[[American football]]== * January 14 – The [[National Football League]] has its first [[1951 Pro Bowl|Pro Bowl]] Game ([[Los Angeles]]). * September 28 – [[Norm Van Brocklin]] sets NFL single game record for most passing yards (554) helping [[Los Angeles Rams]] beat [[New York Yanks]] 48–21. * [[1951 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[1951 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] won 24–17 over [[1951 Cleveland Browns season|the Cleveland Browns]]. * [[1951 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] (1950 season): ** The [[Oklahoma Sooners]] lose 13-7 to the [[Kentucky Wildcats]]; still awarded the college football national championship by [[AP Poll|AP]] and [[Coaches Poll]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1950–51 Football League|First Division]] – [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] win the [[1950–51 in English football|1950–51]] title. * [[1950–51 FA Cup|FA Cup]] – [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] beat [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] 2–0. '''Spain''' * [[1950–51 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Atlético Madrid]] '''Italy''' * [[1950–51 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[A.C. Milan|Milan]]. '''Germany''' * [[1951 German football championship|German football championship]] won by [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]]. '''Portugal''' * [[1950–51 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting C.P.]]. '''France''' * [[1950–51 French Division 1|French Division 1]] won by [[OGC Nice|Nice]].
==[[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]]== The [[Athletics (track and field)|athletics competition]] at the [[1951 Pan American Games]] is held in [[Buenos Aires, Argentina]]. [[Mal Whitfield]] of the USA wins gold medals in three events: 400m, 800m and 4 × 400 m relay.
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1951 VFL season|Victorian Football League]]''' * 29 September − [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] wins the 55th VFL Premiership defeating [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] 11.15 (81) to 10.10 (70) in [[1951 VFL Grand Final|the 1951 VFL Grand Final]]. * [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Bernie Smith]] (Geelong) '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' * 29 September − [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|Port Adelaide]] wins its fourteenth SANFL premiership, defeating [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 10.12 (72) to 9.7 (61) after the Magpies lost only one game for the season.<ref>[http://australianfootball.com/clubs/stats/Port%2BAdelaide%2BMagpies/318/1951 Port Adelaide Magpies 1951 season]</ref> * [[Magarey Medal]] awarded to [[John Marriott (footballer)|John Marriott]] ([[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]]) '''[[West Australian Football League|Western Australian National Football League]]''' * October 13 – [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] wins its eleventh WANFL premiership, beating [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 13.10 (88) to 12.13 (85) * [[Sandover Medal]] awarded to [[Fred Buttsworth]] (West Perth)
==[[Baseball]]== * January 29 – baseball signs a six-year [[Major League Baseball All-Star Game|All-Star game]] deal for TV and radio rights for $6 million * September 30 – [[Joe DiMaggio]] plays in his final career regular season game. * October 3 – In one of the most famous finishes in baseball history, [[Bobby Thomson]] of the [[History of the New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] hits a three-run [[walk-off home run]], immortalized as the [[Shot Heard 'Round the World (baseball)|Shot Heard 'Round the World]], to give the Giants a 5–4 win over the [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn Dodgers]] for the [[National League]] title. * [[1951 World Series|World Series]] – [[1951 New York Yankees season|The New York Yankees]] win 4 games to 2 over [[History of the New York Giants (NL)|the New York Giants]]. * [[1951 Japan Series|Japan Series]] – The [[Yomiuri Giants]] win 4 games to 2 over the [[Nankai Hawks]].
==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] – ** Kentucky wins 68–58 over [[Kansas State University]]. * [[1951 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]] – ** [[1950–51 Rochester Royals season|Rochester Royals]] win 4 games to 3 over [[1950–51 New York Knicks season|the New York Knicks]] * The seventh European basketball championship, [[Eurobasket 1951]], is won by the [[Soviet Union national basketball team|Soviet Union]].
==[[Boxing]]== * July 10 – [[Randy Turpin]] becomes the middleweight [[boxing]] champion by defeating [[Sugar Ray Robinson]]. * July 18 – [[Jersey Joe Walcott]] knocks out [[Ezzard Charles]] in round 7 during their bout in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].
==[[Canadian football]]== * [[Grey Cup]] – [[Ottawa Rough Riders]] wins 21–14 over the [[Saskatchewan Roughriders]]
==[[Cycling]]== * [[1951 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] is won by [[Fiorenzo Magni]] of Italy * [[1951 Tour de France|Tour de France]] – [[Hugo Koblet]] of Switzerland
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[World Figure Skating Championships]] – ** Men's champion: [[Dick Button]], United States ** Ladies' champion: [[Jeannette Altwegg]], Great Britain ** Pair skating champions: [[Ria Baran]] & [[Paul Falk]], Germany
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1951 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Ben Hogan]] * [[1951 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Ben Hogan]] * [[1951 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Sam Snead]] * [[1951 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Max Faulkner]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Lloyd Mangrum]] – $26,089 * [[1951 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] – United States team wins 9½ to 2½ over the British team. The '''ACSM American Fitness Index Program''' ('''Fitness Index''') is an initiative of the [[American College of Sports Medicine]] that aims to quantitatively measure the overall health and fitness level of the 100 largest cities by population in American.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanfitnessindex.org/about-american-fitness-index/|title=About the ACSM American Fitness Index®|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|deadurl=no|accessdate=October 8, 2018}}</ref> The measure is a composite of indicators for personal health and community resources available for physical activity. The first report, completed in May 2008, ranked the 15 most populous metropolitan areas in the nation, along with [[Indianapolis metropolitan area|Greater Indianapolis]] (where the ACSM is based).<ref name="stanford">{{cite web | url = http://longevity.stanford.edu/mybody/mobility/physicalactivity/AFIndex | title = American College of Sports Medicine creates 'American Fitness Index' | accessdate = 2010-05-26 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100528080919/http://longevity.stanford.edu/mybody/mobility/physicalactivity/AFIndex| archivedate= 28 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Today, the 100 most populous cities are ranked annually. As of 2018, [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, VA]] was ranked as the fittest city in America; [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, OK]] ranked as the least fit city<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.americanfitnessindex.org/rankings/|title=ACSM American Fitness Index Rankings|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=8 October 2018}}</ref>.
The Fitness Index's goal is to provide local policy-makers with the information necessary to improve the health, fitness, and quality of life of community residents by promoting healthier lifestyles and physical activity<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanfitnessindex.org/about-american-fitness-index/|title=About the ACSM American Fitness Index®|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref>.
==Methodology== Ranks and scores are assigned by weighing various indicators and rewarding or penalizing the city as appropriate. These indicators are classified into two broad categories: ''Personal Health'', which measures the health habits and outcomes for city residents, including their physical activity, diet, and chronic health problems, and ''Community and Environment'', which includes scores to measure the availability and convenience of local parks, farmers' markets, alternative transportation, and community recreation facilities like pools, tennis courts, and baseball diamonds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americanfitnessindex.org/methodology/|title=Methodology|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.americanfitnessindex.org/rankings 2018 American Fitness Index Rankings]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Acsm American Fitness Index}} [[Category:Physical exercise]]

[[File:NYC Marathon wheelchair.jpg|thumb|A [[New York City Marathon]] competitor uses a racing wheelchair.]] '''Assistive technology in sport''' is an area of technology design that is growing. Assistive technology is the array of new devices created to enable sports enthusiasts who have disabilities to play. Assistive technology may be used in [[disabled sports]], where an existing sport is modified to enable players with a disability to participate; or, assistive technology may be used to invent completely new sports with athletes with disabilities exclusively in mind.
An increasing number of people with disabilities are participating in sports, leading to the development of new assistive technology.<ref>{{cite book|last=Scherer, Marcia and Stefano Federici|title=Assistive Technology Assessment Handbook|year=2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781439838655|pages=425}}</ref> Assistive technology devices can be simple, "low-tech", or they may use highly advanced technology, with some even using computers. Assistive technology for sports may also be simple or advanced.<ref>{{cite web|title=Assistive technologies|url=http://www.understandingdisability.org/AssistiveTechnologies|publisher=Spaulding Framingham|accessdate=September 5, 2012}}</ref> Accordingly, assistive technology can be found in sports ranging from local community recreation to elite Paralympic games. More complex assistive technology devices have been developed over time, and as a result, sports for people with disabilities "have changed from being a clinical therapeutic tool to an increasingly competition-oriented activity".<ref>{{cite book|last=Scherer, Marcia and Stefano Federici|title=Assistive Technology Assessment Handbook|year=2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781439838655|pages=427}}</ref>
==Assistive devices== Assistive devices can enable exercise and training, on top of enabling participation in a sport. Below are some of the assistive devices currently available for different impairments:
* Mobility impairments:<ref>{{cite web|title=Illness and Disability: Gear for sports and fitness |url=http://www.girlshealth.gov/disability/disbody/assist.cfm |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services |accessdate=September 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916081925/http://www.girlshealth.gov/disability/disbody/assist.cfm |archivedate=September 16, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Assistive technologies|url=http://www.understandingdisability.org/AssistiveTechnologies|publisher=Spaulding Framingham|accessdate=September 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Assistive technology 101 |url=http://www.fctd.info/factsheet/at101 |publisher=The Family Center on Technology and Disability |accessdate=September 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917140937/http://www.fctd.info/factsheet/at101 |archivedate=September 17, 2012 }}</ref> ** Light-weight wheelchairs for basketball, tennis, and racing ** All-terrain wheelchairs with rugged frames and wheels for rolling over unpaved surfaces, like hiking trails, snow, or beach sand ** [[Handcycle]]s, or [[recumbent bicycle]]s, which are like bicycles with pedals and steering using only the rider's arms ** Cross-country sit skis that allow skiers to sit down and push along the trail with tips that dig into the snow ** Weights that users strap onto their wrists rather than having to hold them with the hands ** Gym equipment that lets users stay in a wheelchair while using arm exercise machines ** Mitts with Velcro straps that help users to hold onto an exercise machine if their grip isn’t strong enough ** Elastic band or tubes that exercise muscles through resistance instead of weight ** [[Paramobile device]]s such as specialized [[golf cart]]s with support for standing assist players with mobility disabilities ** Bowling balls with hand grips assist bowlers with limited use of their hands ** One-handed fishing rods assist fishers who have limited mobility * Visual impairments:<ref>{{cite web|title=Illness and Disability: Gear for sports and fitness |url=http://www.girlshealth.gov/disability/disbody/assist.cfm |publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services |accessdate=September 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916081925/http://www.girlshealth.gov/disability/disbody/assist.cfm |archivedate=September 16, 2012 }}</ref> ** Softballs that beep, so that people with visual problems can locate the ball to hit and catch it ** Basketballs with jingle bells inside for people who have limited or no eyesight <gallery> File:First Swing program assistive tech golf.jpg|A golfer with a leg amputation uses an adaptive golf cart that has a chest strap to help him maintain his balance while standing on one leg. File:Wheelchair Curling Medal Round, Vancouver 2010 Paralympics.jpg|Wheelchair [[Curling (sport)|curling]] uses a specially adapted long stick to launch the "rock" down the ice. These players are delivering rocks in the 2010 Vancouver Paralympics. File:Scott McPhee and Kieran Modra riding 02.jpg|Australian Paralympic athletes using a two-seated [[tandem cycling|tandem racing bicycle]]; the visually impaired cyclist pedals in rear, while a sighted "pilot" sits in the front. </gallery>
==Sports using assistive technology== Sports that use assistive technology may include the following: {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *Accessible Fishing & Hunting *Accessible Sailing / Boating / Kayaking *Adaptive Archery *Adaptive Bowling *Adaptive Flying *Adaptive Golf *Adaptive Horseback Riding/Equestrian *Adaptive Scuba Diving *Adaptive Shooting *Adaptive Skiing & Snowboarding *Adaptive Table Tennis *Adaptive Water Sports *Extreme Wheelchair Sports *Handcycling *Power Soccer *Quad Rugby *Sled, Floor & Power Hockey *Wheelchair Basketball *Wheelchair Curling *Wheelchair Fencing *Wheelchair Lacrosse *Wheelchair Pool and Billiards *Wheelchair Racing and Field Sports *Wheelchair Baseball *Wheelchair Softball *Wheelchair Table Tennis *Wheelchair Tennis *Wheelchair Volleyball *Wheelchair Weightlifting {{div col end}} Many of the sports listed above have attained international elite sport status, being included in the [[Paralympic Games]].
===Sports requiring assistive technology=== Some sports have developed with the goal of creating a challenge that players with a disability could enjoy. These sports require assistive technology for all players as part of the game. Some examples are: [[Sled hockey|Sledge (sled) hockey]]; [[wheelchair basketball]]; [[adaptive sailing]], with boats designed especially for sailors with disabilities; [[Nordic skiing|Nordic (cross-country) skiing]] with "sit-ski" buckets; and [[handcycle|handcycling]] races.
==Sport wheelchair design== Sport wheelchairs are designed for the requirements of specific sports. Power chairs can also be fitted with assistive devices that are temporary adaptations to the demands of a sport, such as a kick plate attached to a power chair for [[powerchair football]] (power soccer).
Light-weight frames are a necessity for wheelchairs used in sports requiring sharp, fast turns and overall agility, such as tennis, basketball, and racing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Assistive technology 101 |url=http://www.fctd.info/factsheet/at101 |publisher=The Family Center on Technology and Disability |accessdate=September 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120917140937/http://www.fctd.info/factsheet/at101 |archivedate=September 17, 2012 }}</ref>
Chairs with reinforced frames and impact protection are required for contact sports, such as [[wheelchair rugby]] or [[wheelchair basketball|basketball]].
Racing chairs are designed with bucket seats, angled wheels for improved stability, and a t-frame with a third wheel in front, allowing precision steering as well as improving balance. The athlete and wheelchair are viewed together by some sport researchers as a unified performance system. Improvements can be made to chairs by evaluating the chair and athlete separately or in performance conditions together.<ref>{{cite book|last=Winnick|first=Joseph P.|title=Adapted Physical Education and Sport|year=2010|publisher=Human Kinetics|isbn=9780736089180|pages=572, 575}}</ref> <gallery> File:Bew 75km.JPG|A recumbent racing [[handcycle]] with a streamlined frame and thin road racing wheels. File:Wheelchair rugby game 2.jpg|[[Wheelchair rugby]] players use wheelchairs with strong frames, foot protection and wheel covers, to prevent injury in this contact sport. File:2008 Summer Paralympics Wheelchair tennis - men 2.jpg|[[Wheelchair tennis]] requires agility. These Paralympic players use highly manoeuvrable chairs that can change direction very rapidly Image: US v FR 2007 FIPFA WC.jpg|[[Powerchair football]], also called "power soccer", uses an attachment over the footrest of a [[power wheelchair]] to bump or push the ball. </gallery>
==Prosthetics== Prosthetic devices come in a variety of designs suited to different athletic purposes. Prosthetic legs may be designed for rock climbing, running, or jumping. The technology is designed to attain goals such as greater [[gait]] efficiency when running. The technology is constantly improving, to meet the demands of athletes who set ever-higher sports challenges for themselves.<ref>{{cite book|last=Scherer, Marcia and Stefano Federici|title=Assistive Technology Assessment Handbook|year=2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781439838655|pages=429}}</ref> South African athlete [[Oscar Pistorius]], using energy-storing prosthetic legs, fought for the right to run against able-bodied athletes in the 2008 Olympic and Paralympic Games, and won the right to compete, although he did not meet the qualifying time required for the traditional able-bodied competitions.<ref>{{cite book|last=Scherer, Marcia and Stefano Federici|title=Assistive Technology Assessment Handbook|year=2012|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781439838655|pages=431}}</ref> <gallery> File:Paralympics - AIS athletics track visit 095.JPG|A Paralympic track athlete walks with a prosthetic leg designed for racing. File:Prosthetic leg cycling.jpg|A prosthetic leg designed for bicycle racing. Adaptations can attach the prosthetic foot to the pedal during riding. File:US Navy 101112-N-6320H-071 Peter Harsch, head of the Prosthetics Division at Naval Medical Center San Diego, configures a custom-built Cheetah high.jpg|The Prosthetics Division at Naval Medical Center San Diego, configures a custom-built Cheetah high-performance carbon fiber foot designed for sprinting. File:US Navy 071012-N-8327R-048 Spc. Saul Martinez, who sustained injury during combat, attaches his prosthetic leg after climbing the new 30-foot wall in the Comprehensive Combat and Complex Casualty Care (C5) facility.jpg|Climbing a rock wall is made more accessible with specially designed prosthetic legs. </gallery>
==Functional classification== Functional classification systems are used to evaluate and categorize athletes in elite sports, the classification determines the type and extent of assistive technology use by the athlete.
==Organizations== Organizations and associations at the national and international level support the development of adaptive sport and recreation, often through the use of assistive technology for players. These organizations are "growing in number and scope".<ref>{{cite book|last=Wendt|first=Oliver|title=Assistive Technology: Principles and Applications for Communication Disorders and Special Education|year=2011|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing|isbn=9781780522944|pages=474}}</ref> *[[International Paralympic Committee]] - the global body responsible for many sports up to international elite level competition. *[[Disabled Sports USA]] - The national organization that provides over 40 different adaptive sports to over 60,000 people with disabilities in the US through a network of over 100 community-based chapters.<ref>Candus Thomson, [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-07-31/sports/bs-sp-disabled-kilimanjaro-climber-20100731-12_1_mount-kilimanjaro-disabled-veterans-disabled-sports-usa "Disabled veterans vow to conquer Mount Kilimanjaro"], ''Baltimore Sun'', July 31, 2010</ref><ref>A.G. Sulzberger, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/04/us/04paraglide.html?_r=2 "Accustomed to Wheels, Thrill-Seeking Injured Veterans Take Wing"], ''The New York Times'', September 3, 2011</ref> * [[Adapted Physical Activity Council]] (APAC), a council of the [[American Association for Physical Activity and Recreation]]
==See also== *[[Assistive technology]] *[[Inclusive recreation]] *[[Paralympics]]
